messageBody:
I have only been using JUnit for a few months and I am focusing on
creating "best practices" templates for our development team.

I would greatly appreciate the insight of more experienced users on
the following issue.

Because an exception caught by the JUnit framework is an error, when
testing a method that throws exceptions, it is best to include those
exceptions in the throws clause of the test method (or even add a
"throws Exception" to most test methods).

If you allow your exceptions to be caught by the framework, the
framework will create an "error" and you will get a clear and
complete stack trace for the exception that is being thrown. If you
attempt to catch exceptions and call a fail method in the catch
block, you will get an incomplete stack trace that includes an
AssertionFailedError from JUnit (unless of course you write your own
test runner).

So the correct template would be:

public void testMethod() throws Exception {

returnValue = methodCall(args);

assertTrue(some condition);
}

The following template would be less correct:

public void testMethod() {

try {
returnValue = methodCall(args);

} catch (Exception e){

fail("Exception should not be thrown: " + e);
}

assertTrue(some condition);
}

In general, test methods should be very lean and focus specifically
on the condition being tested; let the framework handle the rest.



--- Mike Clark <mike@...> wrote:
> Mike Duffy wrote:
>
> > Is the following statment true?
> >
> > Within JUnit, an exception caught by the framework is an error.
>
> It appears that with the exception (no pun intended!) of the
> java.lang.ThreadDeath error, all other raised exceptions are
> considered
> errors rather than failures.
>
> Mike
